lines.text: Enter FALSTAFF and MISTRESS FORD

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Mistress Ford, your sorrow hath eaten up my sufferance. I see you are obsequious in your love, and I profess requital to a hair's breadth; not only, Mistress Ford, in the simple office of love, but in all the accoutrement, complement and ceremony of it. But are you sure of your husband now?

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: He's a-birding, sweet Sir John.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: [Within]  What, ho, gossip Ford! what, ho!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Step into the chamber, Sir John.
Exit FALSTAFF
Enter MISTRESS PAGE

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: How now, sweetheart! who's at home besides yourself?

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Why, none but mine own people.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Indeed!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: No, certainly. Speak louder.
Aside to her

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Truly, I am so glad you have nobody here.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Why?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Why, woman, your husband is in his old lunes again: he so takes on yonder with my husband; so rails against all married mankind; so curses all Eve's daughters, of what complexion soever; and so buffets himself on the forehead, crying, 'Peer out, peer out!' that any madness I ever yet beheld seemed but tameness, civility and patience, to this his distemper he is in now: I am glad the fat knight is not here.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Why, does he talk of him?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Of none but him; and swears he was carried out, the last time he searched for him, in a basket; protests to my husband he is now here, and hath drawn him and the rest of their company from their sport, to make another experiment of his suspicion: but I am glad the knight is not here; now he shall see his own foolery.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: How near is he, Mistress Page?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Hard by; at street end; he will be here anon.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: I am undone! The knight is here.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Why then you are utterly shamed, and he's but a dead man. What a woman are you!--Away with him, away with him! better shame than murder.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Which way should be go? how should I bestow him? Shall I put him into the basket again?
Re-enter FALSTAFF

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: No, I'll come no more i' the basket. May I not go out ere he come?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Alas, three of Master Ford's brothers watch the door with pistols, that none shall issue out; otherwise you might slip away ere he came. But what make you here?

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: What shall I do? I'll creep up into the chimney.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: There they always use to discharge their birding-pieces. Creep into the kiln-hole.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Where is it?

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: He will seek there, on my word. Neither press, coffer, chest, trunk, well, vault, but he hath an abstract for the remembrance of such places, and goes to them by his note: there is no hiding you in the house.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: I'll go out then.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: If you go out in your own semblance, you die, Sir John. Unless you go out disguised--

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: How might we disguise him?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Alas the day, I know not! There is no woman's gown big enough for him otherwise he might put on a hat, a muffler and a kerchief, and so escape.

lines.speaker: falstaff
lines.text: Good hearts, devise something: any extremity rather than a mischief.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: My maid's aunt, the fat woman of Brentford, has a gown above.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: On my word, it will serve him; she's as big as he is: and there's her thrummed hat and her muffler too. Run up, Sir John.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Go, go, sweet Sir John: Mistress Page and I will look some linen for your head.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Quick, quick! we'll come dress you straight: put on the gown the while.
Exit FALSTAFF

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: I would my husband would meet him in this shape: he cannot abide the old woman of Brentford; he swears she's a witch; forbade her my house and hath threatened to beat her.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Heaven guide him to thy husband's cudgel, and the devil guide his cudgel afterwards!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: But is my husband coming?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Ah, in good sadness, is he; and talks of the basket too, howsoever he hath had intelligence.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: We'll try that; for I'll appoint my men to carry the basket again, to meet him at the door with it, as they did last time.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Nay, but he'll be here presently: let's go dress him like the witch of Brentford.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: I'll first direct my men what they shall do with the basket. Go up; I'll bring linen for him straight.
Exit

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Hang him, dishonest varlet! we cannot misuse him enough. We'll leave a proof, by that which we will do, Wives may be merry, and yet honest too: We do not act that often jest and laugh; 'Tis old, but true, Still swine eat all the draff.
Exit
Re-enter MISTRESS FORD with two Servants

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Go, sirs, take the basket again on your shoulders: your master is hard at door; if he bid you set it down, obey him: quickly, dispatch.
Exit

lines.speaker: first servant
lines.text: Come, come, take it up.

lines.speaker: second servant
lines.text: Pray heaven it be not full of knight again.

lines.speaker: first servant
lines.text: I hope not; I had as lief bear so much lead.
Enter FORD, PAGE, SHALLOW, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Ay, but if it prove true, Master Page, have you any way then to unfool me again? Set down the basket, villain! Somebody call my wife. Youth in a basket! O you panderly rascals! there's a knot, a ging, a pack, a conspiracy against me: now shall the devil be shamed. What, wife, I say! Come, come forth! Behold what honest clothes you send forth to bleaching!

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Why, this passes, Master Ford; you are not to go loose any longer; you must be pinioned.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Why, this is lunatics! this is mad as a mad dog!

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: Indeed, Master Ford, this is not well, indeed.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: So say I too, sir. Come hither, Mistress Ford; Mistress Ford the honest woman, the modest wife, the virtuous creature, that hath the jealous fool to her husband! I suspect without cause, mistress, do I?
Re-enter MISTRESS FORD

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Heaven be my witness you do, if you suspect me in any dishonesty.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Well said, brazen-face! hold it out. Come forth, sirrah!
Pulling clothes out of the basket

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: This passes!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Are you not ashamed? let the clothes alone.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: I shall find you anon.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: 'Tis unreasonable! Will you take up your wife's clothes? Come away.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Empty the basket, I say!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Why, man, why?

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Master Page, as I am a man, there was one conveyed out of my house yesterday in this basket: why may not he be there again? In my house I am sure he is: my intelligence is true; my jealousy is reasonable. Pluck me out all the linen.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: If you find a man there, he shall die a flea's death.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Here's no man.

lines.speaker: shallow
lines.text: By my fidelity, this is not well, Master Ford; this wrongs you.

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: Master Ford, you must pray, and not follow the imaginations of your own heart: this is jealousies.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Well, he's not here I seek for.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: No, nor nowhere else but in your brain.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Help to search my house this one time. If I find not what I seek, show no colour for my extremity; let me for ever be your table-sport; let them say of me, 'As jealous as Ford, Chat searched a hollow walnut for his wife's leman.' Satisfy me once more; once more search with me.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: What, ho, Mistress Page! come you and the old woman down; my husband will come into the chamber.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Old woman! what old woman's that?

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Nay, it is my maid's aunt of Brentford.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: A witch, a quean, an old cozening quean! Have I not forbid her my house? She comes of errands, does she? We are simple men; we do not know what's brought to pass under the profession of fortune-telling. She works by charms, by spells, by the figure, and such daubery as this is, beyond our element we know nothing. Come down, you witch, you hag, you; come down, I say!

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Nay, good, sweet husband! Good gentlemen, let him not strike the old woman.
Re-enter FALSTAFF in woman's clothes, and MISTRESS PAGE

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Come, Mother Prat; come, give me your hand.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: I'll prat her. Out of my door, you witch, you hag, you baggage, you polecat, you runyon! out, out! I'll conjure you, I'll fortune-tell you.
Beating him
Exit FALSTAFF

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Are you not ashamed? I think you have killed the poor woman.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Nay, he will do it. 'Tis a goodly credit for you.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Hang her, witch!

lines.speaker: sir hugh evans
lines.text: By the yea and no, I think the 'oman is a witch indeed: I like not when a 'oman has a great peard; I spy a great peard under his muffler.

lines.speaker: ford
lines.text: Will you follow, gentlemen? I beseech you, follow; see but the issue of my jealousy: if I cry out thus upon no trail, never trust me when I open again.

lines.speaker: page
lines.text: Let's obey his humour a little further: come, gentlemen.
Exeunt FORD, PAGE, SHALLOW, DOCTOR CAIUS, and SIR HUGH EVANS

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Trust me, he beat him most pitifully.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Nay, by the mass, that he did not; he beat him most unpitifully, methought.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: I'll have the cudgel hallowed and hung o'er the altar; it hath done meritorious service.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: What think you? may we, with the warrant of womanhood and the witness of a good conscience, pursue him with any further revenge?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: The spirit of wantonness is, sure, scared out of him: if the devil have him not in fee-simple, with fine and recovery, he will never, I think, in the way of waste, attempt us again.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: Shall we tell our husbands how we have served him?

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Yes, by all means; if it be but to scrape the figures out of your husband's brains. If they can find in their hearts the poor unvirtuous fat knight shall be any further afflicted, we two will still be the ministers.

lines.speaker: mistress ford
lines.text: I'll warrant they'll have him publicly shamed: and methinks there would be no period to the jest, should he not be publicly shamed.

lines.speaker: mistress page
lines.text: Come, to the forge with it then; shape it: I would not have things cool.
Exeunt
